Question_1.Context: Thrombosis is a condition in which a blood vessel is blocked by blood clots. What is the main cause of thrombosis according to the text?
Question_1.Question: What primarily causes thrombosis?
Question_1.Source: Thrombosis is caused by slow blood flow, excessive coagulation, and vascular damage, each of which acts alone or in combination to form a thrombus.

Question_2.Context: Thrombus formation is affected by the physical shear rate. How does the wall shear rate influence thrombus formation according to the text?
Question_2.Question: How does the wall shear rate affect thrombus formation?
Question_2.A: Increases platelet concentration near the vessel wall
Question_2.Source: The physical shear rate increases the platelet concentration near the vessel wall and activates platelets in that area.

Question_3.Context: Thrombus formation was observed in channels with different stenosis percentages. What was the maximum wall shear rate for the channel with 83.73% stenosis?
Question_3.Question: What was the maximum wall shear rate for the channel with 83.73% stenosis?
Question_3.Source: Each channel has a WSR of 7602.36 s−1 for 71.2% stenosis and 29,850.27 s−1 for 83.73% stenosis when the blood flow was set to 3 mL/h.

Question_4.Context: The study aimed to provide insights into the development of new thrombosis propensity test systems. What was the expected application of the highly reproducible shear rate-based thrombus model?
Question_4.Question: What was the expected application of the highly reproducible shear rate-based thrombus model?
Question_4.B: Fabrication of lab-on-a-chip for drug testing
Question_4.Source: It is expected that manufacturing a highly reproducible shear rate-based thrombus model as a lab-on-a-chip can be applied to the development of shear-sensitive drugs, nanoparticles, and liposomes.

Question_5.Context: The study utilized image analysis to visualize the thrombus formation process. How was the thrombus area calculated in the image analysis process?
Question_5.Question: How was the thrombus area calculated in the image analysis process?
Question_5.A: By measuring the color intensity of the thrombus
Question_5.B: By calculating the ratio of thrombus area to total area in binary images
Question_5.C: By counting the number of platelets in the thrombus
Question_5.D: By analyzing the shape of the thrombus
Question_5.Source: In the last step, the thrombus area was calculated from the ratio of the thrombus area to the total area of the binary image.

Question_6.Context: The study observed thrombus growth in channels with different stenosis percentages. How did the thrombus growth rate differ between the channels with 71.2% and 83.73% stenosis?
Question_6.Question: How did the thrombus growth rate differ between the channels with 71.2% and 83.73% stenosis?
Question_6.A: Thrombus grew faster in the 71.2% stenosis channel
Question_6.B: Thrombus grew faster in the 83.73% stenosis channel
Question_6.C: Thrombus growth rate was similar in both channels
Question_6.D: Thrombus growth rate was not observed
Question_6.Source: In the case of the 83.73% channel, the thrombus grew faster than in the 71.2% channel case.

Question_7.Context: The study mentioned the detachment of thrombi due to high wall shear rates. What is a detached thrombus called according to the text?
Question_7.Question: What is a detached thrombus called?
Question_7.Source: A detached thrombus is referred to as an embolus.

Question_8.Context: The study discussed the analysis of thrombus formation in wide image ranges. How was the analysis improved when the image range was divided into sections?
Question_8.Question: How was the analysis improved when the image range was divided into sections?
Question_8.A: Increased accuracy in thrombus area calculation
Question_8.Source: If the images were divided into sections, each divided image was individually calculated to obtain a range of grayscale values. The non-divided image was set to a grayscale range.

Question_9.Context: The study showed differences in thrombus growth rates in different sections of the channel. Where did the thrombus growth rate appear to be the fastest?
Question_9.Question: Where did the thrombus growth rate appear to be the fastest?
Question_9.Source: In sections 4 and 5, which are close to the stenosis section, the growth rate of the thrombus was the fastest in the early stages of blood perfusion.

Question_10.Context: The study concluded that the image analysis method provided a basis for observing and understanding thrombus formation. What was the main advantage of the image analysis method introduced in the study?
Question_10.Question: What was the main advantage of the image analysis method introduced in the study?
Question_10.A: Accurate measurement of absolute thrombus amount
Question_10.Source: This method makes it possible to determine the location of the formed thrombus and compare the relative size of the thrombus.
